newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland approves Kable sale to Danish firm.
newsitem.headline: Poland approves Kable sale to Danish firm.

text.p: The Polish Securities Commission (KPW) approved on January 30 the sale of a 25-percent stake of the Slaska Fabryka Kabli SA cable maker to Denmark's NKT Cables which would give NKT more than 50 percent of the Polish firm.

"The commission has no objection to NKT Cables' plans of buying a packet of shares which would give it more than 50 percent of votes at the general shareholders meeting of Slaska Fabryka Kabli SA," the commission said in a statement on Friday.
In 1993 NKT Cables and Danish mutual trust Investment Fund for Central Europe bought 25 percent stakes of Kable each.
Kable's president Tadeusz Polok told Reuters the the fund bought the shares with the intention of selling them later.
"It has been known that the fund is not an active investor and after three to four years it will sell its shares....It is a system of supporting Danish expansion," Polok said.
Currently 25 percent of Kable belongs to NKT Cables, 25 percent to Investment Fund for Central Europe, five percent to Bank Slaski and the rest to small investors.
Kable made a net profit of 1.5 million zlotys in 1996 on slaes of 132.7 million.
